title: Murder at Blackwood Manor
introduction: Lord Blackwood is dead. Someone in this house killed him last night, and they're still here. You have limited time before the police arrive.

victim.name: Lord Edmund Blackwood
victim.description: A 68-year-old aristocrat known for his vast fortune and equally vast collection of enemies. He was a stern, unforgiving man who kept many secrets.

suspects.name: Lady Victoria Blackwood
suspects.description: An elegant woman in her early 50s with silver-streaked hair and sharp eyes. She wears expensive jewelry and maintains an air of composure despite the circumstances.
suspects.personality: Composed, calculating, speaks in measured tones. Reveals little emotion but occasionally lets slip bitter remarks about her late husband.
suspects.relationship: Wife of 30 years. Their marriage was more arrangement than love. She stood to inherit the estate.
suspects.alibi: Claims she was in the drawing room reading until she heard the butler's scream.
secrets: Had been secretly consulting with a divorce attorney
Knew about Edmund's hidden will that would leave her nothing

suspects.name: Marcus Blackwood
suspects.description: A nervous man in his late 20s with disheveled hair and ink-stained fingers. He avoids eye contact and fidgets constantly.
suspects.personality: Anxious, defensive, prone to rambling when nervous. Clearly hiding something but terrible at deception.
suspects.relationship: Only son, stood to inherit everything. Had a strained relationship with his demanding father.
suspects.alibi: Says he was in his bedroom writing letters, but cannot produce any letters as evidence.
secrets: Owes significant gambling debts to dangerous people
Overheard arguing with his father earlier that evening

suspects.name: Helena Cross
suspects.description: A sharp-featured woman in her 30s with spectacles and a practical demeanor. She carries a leather notebook everywhere.
suspects.personality: Efficient, observant, speaks precisely. Loyal to her employer but hints at knowing things she shouldn't.
suspects.relationship: Edmund's secretary for 5 years. Knew all his business dealings and personal affairs.
suspects.alibi: Claims she was organizing files in the library until she heard commotion.
secrets: Had discovered Edmund was embezzling from his own company
Was being blackmailed by Edmund to keep quiet

suspects.name: Gerald Finch
suspects.description: A dignified older man with grey temples and impeccable posture. His hands shake slightly when he speaks of the murder.
suspects.personality: Formal, proper, speaks with careful precision. Genuinely distressed by his master's death but maintains professional composure.
suspects.relationship: Served the family for 40 years. Discovered the body and raised the alarm.
suspects.alibi: Was preparing the evening brandy service when he entered the study and found the body.
secrets: Edmund had threatened to fire him without pension next week
Had been stealing small amounts from the household for years

suspects.name: Rose Chen
suspects.description: A quiet woman in her 40s with keen eyes that miss nothing. She moves silently and seems to appear from nowhere.
suspects.personality: Observant, speaks little but when she does, it's significant. Watches everyone carefully.
suspects.relationship: Housekeeper for 8 years. Had access to every room and knew everyone's routines.
suspects.alibi: Says she was in the kitchen preparing for the next day until she heard Gerald's cry.
secrets: Witnessed Victoria and Edmund in a heated argument that afternoon
Knows about the secret passage that leads to the study

rooms.name: Entrance Hall
rooms.description: A grand foyer with marble floors and a sweeping staircase. Family portraits line the walls, their eyes seeming to follow you. A grandfather clock ticks solemnly in the corner.

rooms.name: Study
rooms.description: The crime scene. A wood-paneled room with floor-to-ceiling bookshelves. Lord Blackwood's body has been removed, but chalk marks remain. The desk is in disarray, papers scattered everywhere.

rooms.name: Library
rooms.description: A vast room filled with thousands of leather-bound books. A rolling ladder provides access to the higher shelves. The room smells of old paper and secrets.

rooms.name: Drawing Room
rooms.description: An elegant sitting room with velvet furniture and a crackling fireplace. A half-finished glass of wine sits abandoned on a side table.

rooms.name: Kitchen
rooms.description: A large, well-equipped kitchen with copper pots hanging from the ceiling. The remains of dinner preparation still litter the counters.

rooms.name: Bedroom Wing
rooms.description: A long corridor with doors leading to various bedrooms. The carpet is thick and would muffle footsteps. Several doors stand ajar.

rooms.name: Servants' Quarters
rooms.description: Modest but clean rooms where the staff resides. Personal belongings and small keepsakes hint at lives beyond service.

clues.name: Muddy Footprints
clues.description: Fresh muddy footprints lead from the entrance to the study and back. The pattern suggests someone entered from outside recently.

clues.name: Broken Whiskey Glass
clues.description: Shattered crystal on the floor near the desk. The whiskey has stained the carpet in a splatter pattern, suggesting it was thrown.

clues.name: Torn Letter Fragment
clues.description: A piece of expensive stationery with the words '...cannot pay... they will kill me... need the inheritance now...' written in hasty script.

clues.name: Hidden Will
clues.description: A second will, dated last week, found in a secret compartment of the desk. It leaves everything to charity, disinheriting the entire family.

clues.name: Blood Splatter Pattern
clues.description: The blood pattern suggests the victim was struck from behind while seated. The killer was likely someone he trusted enough to turn his back on.

clues.name: Financial Records
clues.description: Detailed ledgers showing large sums of money being moved to offshore accounts. Someone was systematically draining the family fortune.

clues.name: Threatening Note
clues.description: A typed note reading: 'Pay what you owe or face the consequences. You have until the end of the month.' No signature.

clues.name: Abandoned Wine Glass
clues.description: Lady Victoria's wine glass, only half finished. Unusual for someone who claims to have been reading peacefully all evening.

clues.name: Partially Burned Document
clues.description: Remains of papers in the fireplace. The fragments visible include words like 'divorce' and 'settlement' and 'half the estate.'

clues.name: Missing Carving Knife
clues.description: The kitchen knife block is missing its largest carving knife. The wound on the victim was made by a similar blade.

clues.name: Servants' Schedule
clues.description: A work schedule showing Gerald was supposed to be in the wine cellar at 9 PM, not preparing brandy as he claimed.

clues.name: Gambling IOUs
clues.description: A collection of IOUs totaling over Â£50,000, all signed by Marcus Blackwood. Many are marked 'FINAL NOTICE' in red ink.

clues.name: Witness Account
clues.description: Notes from Rose Chen stating she overheard Marcus shouting at his father: 'I'll kill you before I let you ruin me!' at approximately 8:30 PM.

clues.name: Secret Passage Blueprint
clues.description: An old architectural drawing showing a hidden passage from the servants' quarters directly to the study. Few knew it existed.

clues.name: Termination Notice Draft
clues.description: An unsigned letter dismissing Gerald Finch without pension for 'years of petty theft.' It was to take effect at month's end.

clues.name: Letter Opener
clues.description: A brass letter opener sits on the desk, clean and polished. No blood or scratches.

clues.name: Fireplace Poker
clues.description: The iron poker rests in its stand by the fireplace, covered in undisturbed soot. Hasn't been touched.

clues.name: Silver Candlestick
clues.description: The heavy candlestick sits in its usual place on the mantle. Clean, no marks or damage.

weapons.name: Carving Knife
weapons.description: A large kitchen knife, missing from the knife block

weapons.name: Letter Opener
weapons.description: A sharp brass letter opener from the study desk

weapons.name: Heavy Candlestick
weapons.description: An ornate silver candlestick from the drawing room

weapons.name: Fireplace Poker
weapons.description: A wrought iron poker from the study fireplace

solution.motive: Marcus was drowning in gambling debts and discovered his father planned to disinherit the entire family. In a moment of desperate rage, he confronted his father and, when Edmund refused to help, struck him down with a knife stolen from the kitchen. The muddy footprints are from when he went outside to compose himself before returning to 'discover' the body.
solution.confession: I... I didn't mean for it to happen! He was going to leave everything to charity. CHARITY! While I had loan sharks threatening to break my legs! I just wanted to talk, but he laughed at me, called me weak, said I deserved to suffer for my failures. I grabbed the knife and... and before I knew it, it was over. I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.
